title: What is the symbolism and meaning behind Dante's journey in the Purgatorio?
first_phrase: In this text, the author discusses the symbolic journey of self-improvement, which is not just about moral improvement but also about inner changes. Recent archaeological discoveries reveal the Orphic-Pythagorean mysteries surrounding the idea of Lethe and Mnemosyne, represented by two rivers in the earthly paradise. The former causes forgetfulness, while the latter preserves memory. The text highlights Dante's use of Lethe in his work, but also introduces the lesser-known Eunoè, responsible for the resurrection of the dead. It is a fascinating insight into Dante's guiding philosophy, leading him towards the pagan mysteries.
content: Dante, a meglio affermare il carattere pagano delle catarsi del purgatorio, da cui esce puro e disposto a sallre alle stele, introduce alla fine della cantica non solo il Lete, ma il meno familiare Eunoè (Purg. XXVIII, 131; XXXIII, 127-145), come egli lo chiama, che «la tramortita sua virtù ravviva», ossia che dà a chi è morto la resurrezione, la seconda nascita. Dante vorrebbe pur cantare in parte lo dolce ben che mai non l'avria sazio; ma si dà la combinazione che ei non ha più lungo spazio, sono piene tutte le carte ordite a questa cantica seconda; e sopra tutto non lo lascia più ir lo fren dell'arte. Adelante, Pedro, con juicio. Siamo in pieno mistero pagano. E chi consideri quale sia stata la guida di Dante capisce che doveva condurlo proprio lì.
last_phrase: In conclusion, Dante's introduction of the Lethe and Eunoë at the end of Purgatory emphasizes the pagan character of his conception of catharsis, through which the soul can emerge purified and ready to ascend to the stars. Despite his desire to continue exploring the sweet well that never would have satisfied him, Dante was ultimately unable to do so due to time constraints and the constraints of his art. Nonetheless, his journey through the mysteries of the pagan world underscores his own personal journey from ignorance and prejudice to wisdom and enlightenment, culminating in his initiation by the inimitable Virgil. Ultimately, Dante's work explores the tension between the pagan and Christian conceptions of life, death, and the afterlife, inviting readers to ponder these profound philosophical questions for themselves.
